thread.title: Berlin's Best Chocolate Shops

title: Berlin's Best Chocolate Shops
text:
After devouring savory Berlin street food like currywurst and döner , you may need something altogether sweeter. Luckily, the Hauptstadt is rich in all things - including chocolates. Sample your way through the 6 best chocolate shops in Berlin. Truffle Counter. Erin Porter 
Address : Charlottenstraße 60 (corner of Mohrenstraße), 10117 (Mitte) Telephone : 030 757882440 Hours : Daily 10:00 - 20:00 
Elegant Fassbender & Rausch off of Berlin's most beautiful square, Gendarmenmarkt, only gets more lovely once you step inside. 
First, there is the smell. Molten chocolate overwhelms you as soon as pass the threshold. 
Then, there are the sculptures. Miniature Brandenburger Tor , Reichstag and the Fernsehturm tower above the visitors. 
And there are the colors. Bright crinkly wrappers present every type of chocolate. Magenta sprinkles mark a pomegranate truffle. Gold flakes top another. Crisp white shirts and a green vest outfit the army of workers presenting chocolates. 
Fassbender & Rausch, a full-experience chocolate shop. More » Chocolate Counter. Erin Porter 
Address : Charlottenstraße 60, 10117 (Mitte) Telephone : 030 757882440 Hours : Monday through Wednesday 10:00 – 19:00, Thursday through Saturday 10:00 – 20:00, Sundays 10:00 – 18:00 
Also off of Gendarmenmarkt is Ritter Sport's Bunte SchokoWelt (Colorful chocolate world) - an entirely different kind of chocolate shop. Rainbow colored and kid-friendly, the two level store starts visitors off with a make-your-own-candy bar counter. From there, you can sample every flavor on the market (buttermilk lemon anyone?). Proceed upstairs to learn more about the history of chocolate in the small museum, and then settle into the cafe for - what else? - more chocolate. More » Erich Hamann SchokoLaden 
Address : Brandenburgische Straße 17, 10707 (Wilmersdorf) Telephone : 030 8732086 Hours : Monday to Friday 9:00 - 18:00; Saturday 9:00 - 13:00 
One of Berlin’s oldest chocolate factory, this family-run shop has been open for nearly 100 years. Dedicated to more pure, bitter chocolates the shop and eponymous owner thrived until World War II. The scarcity of ingredients and destruction of his shops looked like the end of Erich Hamann SchokoLaden. 
However, his widow Anna was able to rebuild the shop and its reputation after the war. The son, Gerhard Hamann, his wife Ingrid, and grandson Andreas still serve authentic Hamann chocolates. More » Sawade Berlin
